title: Father of ex-Georgetown student sentenced to four months in admissions scandal
text:
In spring 2016, Semprevivo had celebrated after his son was admitted to Georgetown with backing from the school’s tennis coach. But the good news came with a steep bill, and it wasn’t for tuition.

That April, court records show, Semprevivo used a family trust to pay $400,000 to a charity run by the consultant who had advised the son on his college search.

AD

Semprevivo acknowledged this year in federal court that the check represented something else: a payoff for getting his son into the highly selective university through an athletic recruiting ruse.

AD

His son, it turned out, was just a recreational tennis player and never swung a racket in intercollegiate competition for the Hoyas.

‘Three spots’: Alleged bribery of tennis coach stings Georgetown admissions

Semprevivo pleaded guilty in May to one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud and honest services mail fraud. In addition to the prison term, U.S. District Judge Indira Talwani sentenced him Thursday to two years of supervised release, 500 hours of community service and a $100,000 fine. Talwani indicated that a further hearing will be held on questions about restitution for Georgetown’s legal expenses.

AD

On Sept. 13, Talwani sentenced actress Felicity Huffman to two weeks of incarceration for her role in the scandal. On Tuesday, the judge sentenced businessman Devin Sloane to four months.

With the three sentences, the judge signaled that punishment will vary depending on the scheme each parent pursued. Huffman arranged to purchase a fraudulent admission test score for one of her daughters. Sloane and Semprevivo both conspired to subvert the admissions process at specific universities, which the judge noted had the effect of depriving other applicants of a spot at those schools.

AD

Nineteen other parents accused in the scandal are fighting charges, while a 20th was detained last week in Spain and awaits extradition to Boston.

AD

“I am mortified that I have done this and take full responsibility,” Semprevivo wrote in August in a letter to Talwani. “It is something I will regret for the rest of my life. … It brings me great shame that I have now set a terrible example for college bound students and their parents across the nation.”

In the courtroom, Semprevivo reiterated his regret. At one point he turned to look at and apologize to his wife, who was sitting on a bench. He paused to collect himself, then choked up again when he apologized for bringing shame to his family and friends. “I’ve let you all down,” he said. “This is the first and only crime, and certainly the last crime, I’ll ever commit.”

AD

Prosecutors had sought 13 months in prison for Semprevivo, plus a year of supervised release, a $95,000 fine and a restitution payment to Georgetown of $105,342 that the university incurred in legal fees. Semprevivo’s attorneys asked Talwani for a sentence of probation and community service.

AD

The consultant at the center of the scandal, William “Rick” Singer, has pleaded guilty to racketeering conspiracy and other crimes and is cooperating with federal investigators. Singer sought in various ways to help the children of wealthy clients obtain fake admission test scores and use phony athletics credentials to get into universities through what he called a “side door.”

During the hearing, Talwani lectured parents who sought special treatment for children who already had many advantages. “I think the question you need to ask is what makes your children entitled to a side door?” the judge said.

AD

Georgetown officials declined to comment after the sentence.

AD

For the prestigious Jesuit university in the nation’s capital, the scandal exposed weaknesses in its oversight of athletics. The university quietly ousted its tennis coach, Gordon Ernst, after learning in late 2017 of irregularities in his recruiting.

When federal authorities disclosed the admissions scandal in March 2019, they charged Ernst with racketeering conspiracy. They alleged that Singer paid Ernst more than $2.7 million in bribes over several years in exchange for the coach’s designating at least 12 applicants as recruits. One was Semprevivo’s elder son. (The son was not charged with a crime.) In the year the son was admitted, Georgetown rejected about 84 percent of applicants.

Ernst has pleaded not guilty. His trial date has not been set. Georgetown officials this year announced tighter protocols for reviewing credentials of athletics recruits. They also dismissed two students and are reviewing the records of former students who may be connected to the scandal. Georgetown did not identify the expelled students, but court records indicate that Adam Semprevivo, Stephen Semprevivo’s elder son, was one of them.

AD

AD

In May, Adam Semprevivo filed a federal lawsuit seeking to block his dismissal. He said in the suit that he had been unaware of the steps his father took in 2015 and 2016, working with Singer, that gave rise to questions about his Georgetown application. He said he had been a student at Georgetown in good standing with a 3.18 grade-point average, and he accused the university of an unfair disciplinary process.

Adam Semprevivo dropped the suit in July.

Stephen Semprevivo, a father of two, holds a bachelor’s degree and master’s degree in business administration from Harvard University. He was a successful executive at numerous companies, according to court records. His most recent employer fired him in May.

AD

Sheila Balkan, a criminologist who submitted a letter to the court for Semprevivo, said the businessman fell prey to a corrupt admissions consultant who knew the insecurities of affluent parents.

“The man was adept at finding blind spots in successful people where others saw strengths,” she wrote. “Stephen was, in many ways, an ideal mark for Singer. Harvard had played such a key role early in Stephen’s career that he understood, perhaps better than most people, how seminal the choice of a university can be.”

Anderson reported from Washington.

AD
description: Stephen Semprevivo pleaded guilty to fraud conspiracy after paying $400,000 to help his son get into Georgetown as a phony tennis recruit.
